Determine the sign of f_x and f_y at each indicated point using the contour diagram of f shown below. (The point P is that in the first quadrant, at a positive x and y value; Q through T are located clockwise from P, so that Q is at a positive x value and negative y, etc.)
(a) At point Q,

f_x is
?
positive
negative
and

f_y is
?
positive
negative
.
(b) At point R,

f_x is
?
positive
negative
and

f_y is
?
positive
negative
.
(c) At point S,

f_x is
?
positive
negative
and

f_y is
?
positive
negative
.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Moving right from Q in the direction of increasing x increases f, so f_x(Q) is positive.
Moving up from Q in the direction of increasing y decreases f, so f_y(Q) is negative.
(b) Moving right from R in the direction of increasing x decreases f, so f_x(R) is negative.
Moving up from R in the direction of increasing y decreases f, so f_y(R) is negative.
(c) Moving right from S in the direction of increasing x decreases f, so f_x(S) is negative.
Moving up from S in the direction of increasing y increases f, so f_y(S) is positive.

statement.p: Your monthly car payment in dollars is P = f(P_0,t,r), where P_0 is the amount you borrowed, t is the number of months it takes to pay off the loan, and r percent is the interest rate.

(a) Is \partial P /\partial t positive or negative?
?
positive
negative
Suppose that your bank tells you that the magnitude of \partial P /\partial t is 20.
What are the units of this value?

p.em: (For this problem, write our your units in full, writing dollars for , months for months, percent for , etc. Note that fractional units generally have a plural numerator and singular denominator.)

statement.p:
(b) Is \partial P /\partial r positive or negative?
?
positive
negative
Suppose that your bank tells you that the magnitude of \partial P /\partial r is 15.
What are the units of this value?

p.em: (For this problem, write our your units in full, writing dollars for , months for months, percent for , etc. Note that fractional units generally have a plural numerator and singular denominator.)
For both parts of this problem, be sure you can explain what the practical meanings of the partial derivatives are.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
\partial P /\partial t: The unit is dollars per month (dollars/month). This is the rate at which payments change as the number of months it takes to pay off the loan changes. The sign is negative because payments decrease as the pay-off time increases. Thus \partial P /\partial t = -20 dollars/month.
\partial P /\partial r: The unit is dollars per percentage point (dollars/percent). This is the rate at which payments change as the interest rate changes. The sign is positive because payments increase as the interest rate increases. Thus \partial P /\partial r = 15 dollars/percent.

statement.p: An experiment to measure the toxicity of formaldehyde yielded the data in the table below. The values show the percent, P=f(t,c), of rats surviving an exposure to formaldehyde at a concentration of c (in parts per million, ppm) after t months.
(a) Estimate f_t(18,2):
(b) Estimate f_c(18,2):

p.em: (Be sure that you can give the practical meaning of these two values in terms of formaldehyde toxicity.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We have f(18,2) = 98.
(a) Thus, to estimate f_t(18,2), we can take f_t(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18+2,2) - f(18-2,2)}{4} = \frac{97 - 99}{4} = -0.5. Alternately, we could take either of the two one-sided difference quotients, f_t(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18+2,2) - f(18,2)}{2} = -0.5 or f_t(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18,2) - f(18-2,2)}{2} = -0.5. In each case, the units of f_t are percent per month. This says 18 months after rats are exposed to a formaldehyde concentration of 2 ppm, the percent of rats surviving is decreasing at a rate of about -0.5 per month. In other words, during the 18 month, around an additional -0.5 percent of the rats will die.
(b) Proceeding similarly to find f_c(18,2), we have f_c(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18,2+2) - f(18,2-2)}{4} = \frac{93 - 100}{4} = -1.16667, or, with one-sided difference quotients, f_c(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18,2+2) - f(18,2)}{2} = -1.25 or f_c(18,2) \approx \frac{f(18,2) - f(18,2-2)}{2} = -1. These indicate that if the original concentration increases from 2 by 1 ppm, the percent surviving after 18 months decreases by about 1.17.

statement.p: An airport can be cleared of fog by heating the air. The amount of heat required depends on the air temperature and the wetness of the fog. The figure below shows the heat H(T,w) required (in calories per cubic meter of fog) as a function of the temperature T (in degrees Celsius) and the water content w (in grams per cubic meter of fog). Note that this figure is not a contour diagram, but shows cross-sections of H with w fixed at 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.4.
(a) Estimate H_T(10, 0.2):

p.em: (Be sure you can interpret this partial derivative in practical terms.)

statement.p: (b) Make a table of values for H(T,w) from the figure, and use it to estimate H_T(T,w) for each of the following:
T = 20, w = 0.2 : H_T(T,w) \approx
T = 30, w = 0.2 : H_T(T,w) \approx
T = 20, w = 0.3 : H_T(T,w) \approx
T = 30, w = 0.3 : H_T(T,w) \approx
(c) Repeat (b) to find H_w(T,w) for each of the following:
T = 20, w = 0.2 : H_w(T,w) \approx
T = 30, w = 0.2 : H_w(T,w) \approx
T = 20, w = 0.3 : H_w(T,w) \approx
T = 30, w = 0.3 : H_w(T,w) \approx

p.em: (Be sure you can interpret this partial derivative in practical terms.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The quantity H_T(10,0.2) is approximated by an difference quotient. The first partial derivative with respect to T is approximated by H_T(10,0.2) \approx { H(10+\Delta T, 0.2) - H(10, 0.2)\over \Delta T}, for small \Delta T. We are free to choose \Delta T to find values from the figure we are given. If we take \Delta T = 10, we get the approximation H_T(10,0.2) \approx { H(20, 0.2) - H(10, 0.2)\over 10} \approx {190 - 240\over 10} = -5.
(Note that you may get a different answer if you read different values from the graph.) The geometric meaning of the partial derivative H_T(10,0.2) that we just approximated is the slope of the curve shown in the figure in the text corresponding to w = 0.2 at the point where T= 10.
In practical terms, we have found that for fog at 10^\circ C containing 0.1 g water per m{}^3 of fog, a 1^\circ C increase in temperature will reduce the heat requirement for dissipating the fog by about 1~calories per cubic meter of fog.
(b) We can approximate values of H(T,w) from the figure, giving the table below:
w = 0.1 0.2 0.3 0.4
T = 10 120 240 330 450
T = 20 100 190 260 350
T = 30 80 160 220 300
T = 40 70 130 200 280
This lets us approximate, using a difference quotient, each of the derivatives indicated. For H_T(20,0.2), we have H_T(20,0.2) \approx \frac{(160 - 190)}{10} = -3. (We could, of course, use a left or central difference instead.) Similarly, we have: H_T(30,0.2) \approx -3, H_T(20,w2) \approx -4, H_T(30,0.3) \approx -2.
(c) Using our table of values, we can similarly calculate the partial derivatives with respect to w. For H_w(20,0.2), we have H_w(20,0.2) \approx \frac{(260 - 190)}{0.1} = 700. (We could, of course, use a left or central difference instead.) Similarly, we have: H_w(30,0.2) \approx 600, H_w(20,w2) \approx 900, H_w(30,0.3) \approx 800.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We have f_x = 2ye^{2xy} and f_y = 2xe^{2xy}, so f_{xx} = 4y^{2}e^{2xy}, f_{yy} = 4x^{2}e^{2xy}, and f_{xy} = 2e^{2xy}+4xye^{2xy} = f_{yx} = 2e^{2xy}+4xye^{2xy}.

(a) Check the local linearity of f(x,y) = e^{y}\sin\!\left(x\right) near x=2.5,\ y=-1 by filling in the following table of values of f for x=2.4,\ 2.5,\ 2.6 and y=-1.1,\ -1,\ -0.9. Express values of f with 4 digits after the decimal point.
(b) Next, fill in the table for the values x=2.49,\ 2.5,\ 2.51 and y = -1.01,\ -1,\ -0.99, again showing 4 digits after the decimal point.

Notice if the two tables look nearly linear, and whether the second looks more linear than the first (in particular, think about how you would decide if they were linear, or if the one were more closely linear than the other).
(c) Give the local linearization of f(x,y) = e^{y}\sin\!\left(x\right) at (2.5,-1):
Using the second of your tables:
Using the fact that f_x(x,y) = e^{y}\cos\!\left(x\right) and f_y(x,y) = e^{y}\sin\!\left(x\right):

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a),(b) The two tables of values are shown below
x = 2.4 2.5 2.6
y = -1.1 0.2248 0.1992 0.1716
y = -1 0.2485 0.2202 0.1896
y = -0.9 0.2746 0.2433 0.2096
x = 2.49 2.5 2.51
y = -1.01 0.2209 0.218 0.215
y = -1 0.2231 0.2202 0.2172
y = -0.99 0.2253 0.2224 0.2194
Both tables are nearly linear. To check this, observe that the increments in each row (column) are equal, or nearly so. The second table is more linear due to finer data.
(c) From either table we see that f(2.5,-1)\approx 0.2202. Also, using the second table, f_x(2.5,-1) \approx \frac{f(2.51,-1) - f(2.49,-1)}{.02} = \frac{0.2172 - 0.2231}{0.02} = -0.295, f_y(2.5,-1) \approx \frac{f(2.5,-0.99) - f(2.5,-1.01)}{.02} = \frac{0.2224 - 0.218}{0.02} = 0.22. Using these estimates for the partial derivatives, we get that the local linearization of f around (2.5,-1) is f(x,y) \approx f(2.5,-1)+f_x(2.5,-1)(x-2.5)+f_y(2.5,-1)(y + 1) = 0.2202 + (-0.295)(x - 2.5) + (0.22)(y + 1).
Now we use f_x = e^{y}\cos\!\left(x\right) and f_y = e^{y}\sin\!\left(x\right), giving f_x(2.5,-1) = -0.294724, f_y(2.5,-1) = 0.220166, we have the local linearization of f around (2.5,-1) f(x,y) \approx 0.220166+\left(-0.294724\right)\!\left(x-2.5\right)+0.220166\!\left(y-\left(-1\right)\right). Note that these agree to a reasonable number of decimal places.

statement.p: Suppose that z is a linear function of x and y with slope -4 in the x direction and slope 1 in the y direction.
(a) A change of -0.4 in x and 0.2 in y produces what change in z?
change in z =
(b) If z=7 when x=3 and y=5, what is the value of z when x=2.9 and y=5.1?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Since z is a linear function of x and y with slope -4 in the x direction, and slope 1 in the y direction, we have: z = -4 x + 1 y + c. We can write an equation for changes in z in terms of changes in x and y: \Delta z = (-4 (x + \Delta x) + 1(y + \Delta y) + c) - (-4 x + 1 y + c) = -4 \Delta x + 1 \Delta y. Since \Delta x = -0.4 and \Delta y = 0.2, we have \Delta z = -4 (-0.4) + 1(0.2) = 1.8. So a -0.4 change in x and a 0.2 change in y produces a 1.8 change in z.
(b) As we know that z=7 when x=3 and y=5, the value of z when x=2.9 and y=5.1 will be z = 7 + \Delta z = 7 - 4\Delta x + 1\Delta y. where \Delta z is the change in z when x changes from 3 to 2.9 and y changes from 5 to 5.1. We have \Delta x = 2.9 - 3 = -0.1 and \Delta y = 5.1 - 5 = 0.1. Therefore, when x=2.9 and y=5.1, we have z = 7 - 4 \cdot(-0.1) + 1\cdot(0.1) = 7.5.

If z = \left(x+y\right)e^{y} and x = u^{2}+v^{2} and y = u^{2}-v^{2}, find the following partial derivatives using the chain rule. Enter your answers as functions of u and v.

If z = \sin\!\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right),\qquad x = u\cos\!\left(v\right),\qquad y = u\sin\!\left(v\right), find \partial z/\partial u and \partial z/\partial v. The variables are restricted to domains on which the functions are defined.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since z is a function of two variables x and y which are functions of two variables u and v, the two chain rule identities which apply are: \frac{\partial z}{\partial u} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial u}+ \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial u} and \frac{\partial z}{\partial v} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial v}+ \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial v}
This problem is most easily solved by substitution: z = \sin\!\left(\left(u\cos\!\left(v\right)\right)^{2}+\left(u\sin\!\left(v\right)\right)^{2}\right) = \sin\!\left(u^{2}\right) so \frac{\partial z}{\partial u} = \cos\!\left(u^{2}\right)\cdot 2u, and \frac{\partial z}{\partial v} = 0.
This problem can also be solved using the chain rule but it is more difficult.

statement.p: Let z=g(u,v,w) and u(r,s),v(r,s),w(r,s). How many terms are there in the expression for \partial z/\partial r?
terms

static.solution:
SOLUTION
By the chain rule, \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = g_{u}\cdot u_{r}+g_{v}\cdot v_{r}+g_{w}\cdot w_{r}. Thus, there are 3 terms.

(a) What shape are the level curves of T?

solution.p: SOLUTION
(a) Let k >0 be constant. The level curves have equation k =\frac{110}{x^{2}+y^{2}+2} or x^2 + y^2 = \frac{110}{k} - 2. If \frac{110}{k} - 2 > 0, these equations represent circles in the xy- plane.

At a certain point on a heated metal plate, the greatest rate of temperature increase, 5 degrees Celsius per meter, is toward the northeast. If an object at this point moves directly north, at what rate is the temperature increasing?
degrees Celsius per meter

solution.p: SOLUTION
Let T be the temperature function and P the point. The value of the greatest rate of increase is the magnitude of the gradient. Thus \left| \nabla T (P) \right| = 5.
The gradient points in the northeast direction, so \nabla T (P) = \left \langle 5 \cos (45^o) , 5 \sin (45^o) \right \rangle = \left \langle \frac{5}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} \right \rangle.

A unit vector in the north direction is \mathbf{u} = \langle 0, 1 \rangle, so the rate of change of increase of the temperature in that direction is D_{\mathbf u} T(P) = \nabla T (P) \cdot \mathbf{u} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{2}}

SOLUTION

Thus D> 0, and f_{xx} \lt 0, so k(0,0) is a maximum.

Suppose f(x, y) = xy - ax - by.
(A) How many local minimum points does f have in \mathbf{R}^{2}? (The answer is an integer).
(B) How many local maximum points does f have in \mathbf{R}^{2}?
(C) How many saddle points does f have in \mathbf{R}^{2}?
Let f(x,y) = 2/x + 3/y + 4 x + 5 y in the region R where x, y > 0.
Explain why f must have a global minimum at some point in R (note that R is unbounded---how does this influence your explanation?). Then find the global minimum.
minimum =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The function f is continuous in the region R, but R is not closed and bounded so a special analysis is required.
Notice that f(x,y) tends to \infty as (x,y) tends farther and farther from the origin or tends toward any point on the x or y axis. This suggests that a minimum for f, if it exists, can not be too far from the origin or too close to the axes. For example, if x > 10 then f(x,y) > 4 x > 40, and if y > 10 then f(x,y) > 5 y > 50. If 0\lt x\lt 0.1 then f(x,y) > 2/x > 20, and if 0\lt y\lt 0.1 then f(x,y) > 3/y > 30.
Since f(1,1)=14, a global minimum for f if it exists must be in the smaller region R^\prime: 0.1 \le x \le 10, 0.1 \le y \le 10. The region R^\prime is closed and bounded and so have a minimum value at some point in R^\prime, and since that value is at most 14, it is also a global minimum for all of R.
Since the region R has no boundary, the minimum value must occur at a critical point of f. At a critical point we have f_x = -{2\over x^2} + 4 = 0 = f_y = -{3\over y^2} + 5 = 0. The only critical point is (\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}, \sqrt{\frac{3}{5}}), at which f achieves the minimum value f(\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}},\sqrt{\frac{3}{5}}) = 2\sqrt{8} + 2\sqrt{15}

static.solution:
SOLUTION
At the critical point x=4, y=0, f_x = 2x + A = 8 + A = 0, and f_y = 2y = 0, so that A = -8.
Then, for this to be a minimum, we must have D > 0 and f_{xx} > 0. Here, f_{xx} = 2, f_{yy} = 2, and f_{xy} = 0, so D = 4 - 0 = 4 > 0 and f_{xx} > 0. Thus this is a minimum, as advertised.
For it to occur with a z-coordinate of 25, we must have f(4,0) = -16 + B = 25, so that B = 41.

statement.p: Find three positive real numbers whose sum is 5 and whose product is a maximum.
Enter the three numbers separated by commas:
A closed rectangular box has volume 26\,\mbox{cm}^3. What are the lengths of the edges giving the minimum surface area?
lengths =

p.em: (Give the three lengths as a comma separated list.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Let the sides be x,y, z cm. Then the volume is given by V = xyz = 26.
The surface area S is given by S = 2xy+2xz+2yz. Substituting z = 26/(xy) gives S = 2xy +\frac{52}{y} + \frac{52}{x}. At a critical point, \frac{\partial S}{\partial x} = 2y - \frac{52}{x^2} = 0, and \frac{\partial S}{\partial y} = 2x - \frac{52}{y^2} = 0.
The symmetry of the equations (or by dividing the equations) tells us that x=y and so that 2x - \frac{52}{x^2} = 0, so that x^3 = 26, \quad\mbox{and so}\quad x = 26^{1/3}\mbox{ cm}. Thus the only critical point is x = y = (26)^{1/3} cm, and z = 26/\left ( (26)^{1/3} \cdot (26)^{1/3} \right ) = (26)^{1/3} cm. At the critical point S_{xx} S_{yy}-(S_{xy})^2= \frac{104}{x^3}\cdot\frac{104}{y^3}-2^2= \frac{(104)^2}{x^{3}y^{3}}-4. Since D>0 and S_{xx}>0 at this critical point, the critical point x = y = z = (26)^{1/3} is a local minimum. Since S\rightarrow\infty as x,y\rightarrow\infty, the local minimum is a global minimum.

statement.p: An open rectangular box has volume 30 \mbox{ cm}^3. What are the lengths of the edges giving the minimum surface area?
lengths =

p.em: (Give the three lengths as a comma separated list.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Let the sides of the base be x and y cm. Let the height be z cm. Then the volume is given by xyz = 30 and the surface area, S, is given by S = xy + 2xz + 2yz. Substituting z = 30/(xy) gives S = xy + \frac{60}{y} + \frac{60}{x}. At a critical point \frac{\partial S}{\partial x} = y - \frac{60}{x^2} = 0, and \frac{\partial S}{\partial y} = x - \frac{60}{y^2} = 0.
The symmetry of the equations tells us that x=y, so x - \frac{60}{x^2} = 0, \quad\mbox{and}\quad x^3 = 60, so that x = (60)^{1/3} cm.
Thus the only critical point is x=y=(60)^{1/3} cm and z = 30/((60)^{1/3}\cdot (60)^{1/3}) = (15/2)^{1/3} cm.
At the critical point D = S_{xx}S_{yy}-(S_{xy})^2 =\frac{120}{x^3} \cdot \frac{120}{y^3}-1^2= \frac{120^2}{x^3y^3}-1. Since D>0 and S_{xx}>0 at this critical point, the critical point x = y = (60)^{1/3}, z = (15/2)^{1/3} is a local minimum. Since S\rightarrow\infty as x,y\rightarrow\infty, the local minimum is a global minimum.

statement.p: What is the shortest distance from the surface x y + 6 x + z^2 = 36 to the origin?
distance =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We minimize the square of the distance from the point (x,y,z) to the origin: S=x^2+y^2+z^2. Since z^2 = 36 - x y - 6 x, we have S = x^2 + y^2 + 36 - x y - 6 x. At a critical point \frac{\partial S}{\partial x} = 2 x - y - 6 = 0, and \frac{\partial S}{\partial y} = 2 y - x = 0, so x = 2 y, and 2(2 y) - y - 6 = 0 giving y=2, so x=4 and z^2 = 36 - (4)(2) - 6 (4), so z=\pm 2. We have D= S_{xx}S_{yy}-(S_{xy})^2 =2\cdot2 - (-1)^2 = 4 - 1 > 0, so, since D>0 and S_{xx}>0, the critical points are local minima. Since S\rightarrow\infty as x,y\rightarrow\pm\infty, the local minima are global minima.
If x=4, y=2, z=\pm 2, we have S = 4^2 + 2^2 + 2^2 = 24, so the shortest distance to the origin is \sqrt{24}.

Design a rectangular milk carton box of width w, length l, and height h which holds 510 \mbox{ cm}^3 of milk. The sides of the box cost 3 \ \mbox{cent}/\mbox{cm}^2 and the top and bottom cost 5\ \mbox{cent}/\mbox{cm}^2. Find the dimensions of the box that minimize the total cost of materials used.
dimensions =

p.em: (Enter your answer as a comma separated list of lengths.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The cost of four sides =(2hl+2wh)(3) cents. The cost of top and bottom =(2wl)(5) cents. Thus the total cost C (in cents) of the box is C = 6(hl+wh) + 10 wl. But the volume = wlh = 510, so l = 510/(wh), thus C = \frac{3060}{w} + 6 wh + \frac{5100}{h}. To minimize C, we find the critical points of C by solving C_h = 6 w - \frac{5100}{h^2} = 0, and C_w = 6 h - \frac{3060}{w^2} = 0. We get 6 w h^2 = 5100, \quad\mbox{and}\quad 6 h w^2 = 3060, Since w, h \ne 0, we can divide the first equation by the second, giving \frac{6 w h^2}{6 h w^2} = \frac{5100}{3060}, so \frac{h}{w} = \frac{5}{3}, thus h = \frac{5}{3} w. Substituting this into C_w = 0, we obtain w^3 = 170, so w = 6.73866 and h = 11.2311 cm. Then l = 510/(wh) = 6.73867 cm.
Next we can check that these dimensions minimize the cost C. We find that D=C_{hh}C_{ww}-C^2_{hw} = (\frac{10200}{h^3})(\frac{6120}{w^3}) - 6^2, So that at the critical point, D > 0 and C_{hh} > 0, and thus C has a local minimum at h=11.2311 and w=6.73866. Since C increases without bound as w,h\to 0 or \infty, this local minimum must be a global minimum.
Therefore, the dimensions of the box that minimize the cost are w=6.73866 cm, l=6.73867 cm and h=11.2311 cm.

statement.p: Use Lagrange multipliers to find the maximum and minimum values of f(x,y) = 3 x - 2 y subject to the constraint x^2 + y^2 = 13, if such values exist.
maximum =
minimum =

p.em: (For either value, enter DNE if there is no such value.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Our objective function is f(x,y)= 3 x - 2 y and our equation of constraint is g(x,y) = x^2 + y^2 = 13. To optimize f(x,y) with Lagrange multipliers we solve the following system of equations f_{x}(x,y) = \lambda g_{x}(x,y),\qquad\mbox{so } 3 = 2\lambda x, f_{y}(x,y) = \lambda g_{y}(x,y),\qquad\mbox{so } -2 = 2\lambda y, and g(x,y) = 13,\qquad\mbox{so } x^2 + y^2 = 13. Solving for \lambda gives us \lambda = \frac{3}{2 x} = \frac{-1}{ y}, which we can use to find x in terms of y: x = -\frac{3}{2}\,y. Using this relation in our equation of constraint, we can solve for y: x^2 + y^2 = 13, so (-\frac{3}{2}\, y)^2 + y^2 = 13, and thus ((\frac{3}{2})^2 + 1)\, y^2 = 13. So, solving for y, we have y = \pm 2, and x = \mp 3. Thus, the critical points are (-3,2) and (3,-2). Since the constraint is closed and bounded, maximum and minimum values of f subject to the constraint exist. Evaluating f at the critical points, we find that the maximum value is f(3,-2) = 3(3) + 2(2) = 13 and the minimum value is f(-3,2) = -3(3) - 2(2) = -13.

statement.p: Consider the concentration, C, in mg per liter (L), of a drug in the blood as a function of x, the amount, in mg, of the drug given and t, the time in hours since the injection. For 0 \leq x \leq 4 and t \geq 0, we have C = f(x,t) = t e^{-t(5-x)}.
Graph the following two single variable functions on a separate page, being sure that you can explain their significance in terms of drug concentration.
Using your graph in (a), where is f(4,t)
a maximum? t =
a minimum? t =
Using your graph in (b), where is f(x,1)
a maximum? x =
a minimum? x =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Holding x fixed at 4 means that we are considering an injection of 4 mg of the drug; letting t vary means we are watching the effect of this dose as time passes. Thus the function f(4,t) describes the concentration of the drug in the blood resulting from a 4 mg injection as a function of time. The figure below shows the graph of f(4,t)=t\,e^{- t}. Notice that the concentration in the blood from this dose is at a maximum at 1 hour after injection, and that the concentration in the blood eventually approaches zero. The initial concentration is 0, so the minimum occurs at t = 0.
(b) Holding t fixed at 1 means that we are focusing on the blood 1 hour after the injection; letting x vary means we are considering the effect of different doses at that instant. Thus, the function f(x,1) gives the concentration of the drug in the blood 1 hour after injection as a function of the amount injected. The figure below shows the graph of f(x,1)= e^{-(5-x)}. Notice that f(x,1) is an increasing function of x. This makes sense: If we administer more of the drug, the concentration in the bloodstream is higher. In particular, this means that the maximum concentration occurs at the maximum value of x, 4, and the minimum at x = 0.

statement.p: Use Lagrange multipliers to find the maximum and minimum values of f(x,y) = x^2 y + 3 y^2 - y, subject to the constraint x^2 + y^2 \leq 38.3333333333333
maximum =
minimum =

p.em: (For either value, enter DNE if there is no such value.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We first find the critical points of f: f_x = 2xy = 0, \quad f_y = x^2 + 6 y - 1 = 0. From the first equation, we get either x=0 or y=0. If x=0, from the second equation we get 6 y - 1 = 0, so y=1/6. If instead y=0, then from the second equation x=\pm 1. We conclude that the critical points are (0,1/6), (1,0), and (-1,0). All three critical points satisfy the constraint x^2+y^2\le 38.3333333333333.
The Lagrange conditions, \nabla f= \lambda\nabla g, are: 2xy=\lambda 2x,\qquad x^2 + 6 y - 1 =\lambda 2y. From the first equation, when x\neq 0, we divide by 2x to get \lambda=y. Substituting into the second equation, we get x^2 + 6 y - 1 = 2y^2. Then using x^2 = 38.3333333333333 - y^2 from the constraint, we have 38.3333333333333 - y^2 + 6 y - 1 = 2 y^2, so 3 y^2 - 6 y - 37.3333333333333 = 0. Factoring, we get (3y + 8 )( y - 4.66666666666667 ) = 0, so y = -2.66666666666667 or y = 4.66666666666667. From the constraint, we get x=\pm \sqrt{31.2222222222222} when y=-2.66666666666667 and x=\pm \sqrt{16.5555555555555} for y=4.66666666666667.
If instead x=0, so that we cannot divide by x in the first Lagrange equation, then from the constraint, y=\pm \sqrt{38.3333333333333}.
Summarizing, the following points are either critical points or satisfy the Lagrange conditions: (\pm 1,0),(0,1/6),(\pm \sqrt{31.2222222222222}, -2.66666666666667),(\pm \sqrt{16.5555555555555}, 4.66666666666667), (0, -\sqrt{38.3333333333333}), \mbox{ and } (0, \sqrt{38.3333333333333}). These are the candidates for global maximum or minimum points. The corresponding values for f(x,y)=x^2 y + 3 y^2 - y are: 0, -0.083, -59.259, 137.926, 121.191, \mbox{ and } 108.809. The largest value is 137.926 at the point (\pm \sqrt{16.5555555555555},4.66666666666667), and the smallest value is -59.2593 at (\pm \sqrt{31.2222222222222},-2.66666666666667),

Find the minimum distance from the point (1,1,15) to the paraboloid given by the equation z=x^2+y^2.
Minimum distance =

Note: If you need to find roots of a polynomial of degree \geq 3, you may want to use a calculator of computer to do so numerically. Also be sure that you can give a geometric justification for your answer.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Let (x,y,z) be a point on the paraboloid. The square of the distance from (x,y,z) to the point (1,1,15) is given by f(x,y,z) = (x-1)^2 + (y-1)^2 + (z-15)^2, and so we wish to minimize f(x,y,z) subject to the constraint g(x,y,z) = x^2+y^2-z = 0. We look for solutions to the equations \nabla f = \lambda\nabla g and g=0: 2(x-1) = 2\lambda x, 2(y-1) = 2\lambda y, 2(z-15) = -\lambda, and x^2+y^2-z = 0. If \lambda=0, the first three equations would imply that (x,y,z)=(1,1,15), which does not satisfy the fourth equation and so \lambda\ne 0. If collect terms in x and y in the first and second equations, respectively, we get (1 - \lambda) x = 1, and (1 - \lambda) y = 1. Note that we cannot have \lambda = 1, x = 0 or y = 0, and so can divide these two equation to solve for y, getting y = x.
If we divide the first and third equations we got from the Lagrange multipliers method, we have \frac{x - 1}{z - 15} = -2x, so that z = 15 - \frac12(1 - \frac{1}{x}).
We can then plug all of these into the last equation, the constraint. This gives x^2 + x^2 - 15 + \frac12(1 - \frac{1}{x}) = 0. Multiplying by x and collecting terms, we have 4 x^3 - 29 x - 1 = 0. Let h(x) = 4 x^3 - 29 x - 1. Clearly h(-3) \lt 0, h(-\frac12) > 0, h(0) \lt 0 and h(3) > 0. Thus there must be roots lying between x = -3 and x = -0.5, between x = -0.5 and x = 0, and between x = 0 and x = 3. We can locate these numerically using a calculator or computer program, to find x = -2.675172533, \quad x = -0.03448841687, \quad\mbox{and}\quad x = 2.70966095. Then, using the equations for y and z in terms of x, we have the corresponding values of y and z, and therefore have three solutions to the Lagrange multiplier equations: x_1 = -2.675172533, y_1 = -2.675172533, z_1 = 14.3130961626353, x_2 = -0.03448841687, y_2 = -0.03448841687, z_2 = 0.0023789017963978, and x_3 = 2.70966095, y_3 = 2.70966095, z_3 = 14.6845249279098.
The distances (squared) from the paraboloid are d_1 = d(x_1,y_1,z_1) = 27.4856231764217, d_2 = d(x_2,y_2,z_2) = 227.068971174558, and d_3 = d(x_3,y_3,z_3) = 5.94540564902012, so that the minimum distance is \sqrt{d_3} = 2.43832.
Note that the geometric interpretation of this is that it is the length of a perpendicular line segment drawn from the paraboloid to the point.

statement.p: For each value of \lambda the function h(x,y) = x^2 + y^2 - \lambda(2 x + 6 y - 16) has a minimum value m(\lambda).
(a) Find m(\lambda)

p.em: (Use the letter L for \lambda in your expression.)

statement.p: (b) For which value of \lambda is m(\lambda) the largest, and what is that maximum value?
maximum m(\lambda) =
(c) Find the minimum value of f(x,y)=x^2+y^2 subject to the constraint 2 x + 6 y = 16 using the method of Lagrange multipliers and evaluate \lambda.
minimum f =

p.em: (How are these results related to your result in part (b)?)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The critical points of h(x,y) occur where h_x(x,y) = 2 x - 2 \lambda = 0 and h_y(x,y) = 2 y - 6 \lambda = 0. The only critical point is (x,y) = ( \lambda, 3 \lambda) and it gives a minimum value for h(x,y). That minimum value is m(\lambda) = h( \lambda, 3 \lambda) = \lambda^2 + 9 \lambda^2 - \lambda( 2 \lambda + 18 \lambda - 16 ) or m(\lambda) = -10 \lambda^2 + 16 \lambda.
(b) The maximum value of m(\lambda)= -10 \lambda^2 + 16\lambda occurs at a critical point, where m'(\lambda) = -20 \lambda + 16 = 0. At this point, \lambda = 0.8 and m(0.8)= 6.4.
(c) We want to minimize f(x,y)=x^2+y^2 subject to the constraint g(x,y)=16, where g(x,y) = 2 x + 6 y. The method of Lagrange multipliers has us solve 2x = 2\lambda, 2y = 6\lambda, and 2 x + 6 y = 16. We can see that this gives the same solutions for x and y as we obtained in part (a), and then, plugging in to the third equation, we have 2 \lambda + 18 \lambda = 16. Thus we get the same \lambda as before: \lambda = 0.8, so that the minimum value of f is f(\lambda, 3\lambda), where \lambda = 0.8, or f_{\mbox{min}} = 6.4.
Note that the two question have the same answer. This makes sense, because in the first problem the largest minimum value will clearly occur when 2 x + 6 y = 16, which is the constraint in the third equation.

(a) If \sum_{i=1}^3 x_i = 5, find the values of x_1, x_2, x_3 making \sum_{i=1}^3 {x_i}^2 minimum.

p.em: (Give your values as a comma separated list.)

statement.p: (b) Generalize the result of part (a) to find the minimum value of \sum_{i=1}^n{x_i}^2 subject to \sum_{i=1}^n x_i=5.
minimum value =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Let f(x_1,x_2,x_3)=\sum_{i=1}^3{x_i}^2 = {x_1}^2 + {x_2}^2 + {x_3}^2 and g(x_1,x_2,x_3)=\sum_{i=1}^3 x_i = 5. Then \nabla f = \lambda\nabla g gives 2x_1 = \lambda = 2x_2 = 2x_3. so x_1 = x_2 = x_3 = \frac{\lambda}2. Then x_1+x_2+x_3 = 5 gives 3\frac{\lambda}{2} = 5\quad\hbox{ so } \quad \lambda = \frac{10}{3}. Thus x_1 = x_2 = x_3 = \frac{5}{3}.
These values of x_1, x_2,x_3 give the minimum (rather than maximum) because the value of without bound as x_2,x_2,x_3\to\infty.
(b) A similar argument shows that \sum_{i=1}^nx_i has its minimum value subject to \sum_{i=1}^nx_i = 5 when x_1=x_2=\cdots= x_n=\frac{5}n. Then the minimum value is \sum_1^n \left(\frac{5}{n}\right)^2 = n\cdot \left(\frac{5}{n}\right)^2 = \frac{25}{n}.

statement.p: (c) Pair of intersecting straight lines: the plane =

p.em: (Give your answer by specifying the variable in the first answer blank and a value for it in the second.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) If x is constant, we get z = 3 x^2 + a, for some value of a, so that the cross-sections are upward-opening parabolas.
(b) If y is constant, we get z = -9 y^2 + a, for some value of a, so that the cross-sections are downward-opening parabolas.
(c) If z is constant and equal to 1, we get y = \pm \sqrt{3} x, which are two intersecting straight lines.

For underestimates or overestimates, consistently use either the lower left-hand corner or the upper right-hand corner of each rectangle in a subdivision, as appropriate.
(a) Without subdividing R,
Underestimate =
Overestimate =

Underestimate =
Overestimate =

Let R be the rectangle with vertices (0,0), (2,0), (2,2), and (0,2) and let f(x,y) = \sqrt{3xy}.
(a) Find reasonable upper and lower bounds for \int_{R}f\,dA without subdividing R.
upper bound =
lower bound =

(b) Estimate \int_{R}f\,dA three ways: by partitioning R into four subrectangles and evaluating f at its maximum and minimum values on each subrectangle, and then by considering the average of these (over and under) estimates.
overestimate: \int_{R}f\,dA \approx
underestimate: \int_{R}f\,dA \approx
average: \int_{R}f\,dA \approx

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) If we take the partition of R consisting of just R itself, we get \mbox{Lower bound }= \mbox{min}_R f\cdot A_R=0\cdot (2-0)(2-0)=0. Similarly, we get \mbox{Upper bound } = \hbox{max}_R f\cdot A_R = 2\sqrt{3}\cdot (2-0)(2-0)=8\sqrt{3}.
(b) The estimates asked for are just the upper and lower sums. We partition R into subrectangles R_{(a,b)} of width 1 and height 1, where (a,b) is the lower-left corner of R_{(a,b)}. The subrectangles are then R_{(0,0)}, R_{(1,0)}, R_{(0,2)}, and R_{(2,2)}. Then we find the lower sum \mbox{Lower } =\sum_{(a,b)}A_{R_{(a,b)}}\cdot\min_{R_{(a,b)}}f = \sum_{(a,b)} 1\cdot (\mbox{Min of }f \mbox{ on }R_{(a,b)}). The minimum occurs at the lower-left corner of each rectangle, so \mbox{Lower } = 1\cdot( f(0,0) + f(1,0) + f(0,1) + f(1,1) ) = 4\sqrt{3}.
Similarly, the upper sum is \mbox{Upper } = 1\sum_{(a,b)}(\mbox{Max of }f \mbox{ on }R_{(a,b)}), so \mbox{Upper } = 1(f(2,2)+f(4,2)+f(2,4)+f(4,4)) = 1(3\sqrt3 + 2\sqrt{6}). The upper sum is an overestimate and the lower sum is an underestimate, so we can get a better estimate by averaging them to get 1(2\sqrt3 + \sqrt6).

statement.p: Using Riemann sums with four subdivisions in each direction, find upper and lower bounds for the volume under the graph of f(x,y) = 1+2xy above the rectangle R with 0\le x\le 2,\quad 0\le y \le 4.
upper bound =
lower bound =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Partition R into subrectangles with the lines x=0, x=0.5, x=1, x=1.5, and x=2 and the lines y=0, y=1, y=2, y=3, and y=4. Then we have 16 subrectangles, each of which we denote R_{(a,b)}, where (a,b) is the location of the lower-left corner of the subrectangle.
We want to find a lower bound and an upper bound for the volume above each subrectangle. The lower bound for the volume of R_{(a,b)} is 0.5 ( \mbox{Min of } f \mbox{ on } R_{(a,b)}) because the area of R_{(a,b)} is 0.5\cdot 1=0.5. The function f(x,y) = 1+2xy increases with both x and y over the whole region R. Thus, \mbox{Min of } f \mbox{ on } R_{(a,b)} = f(a,b) = 1+2ab, because the minimum on each subrectangle is at the corner closest to the origin.
Similarly, \mbox{Max of } f \mbox{ on } R_{(a,b)} = f(a+0.5,b+1) = 1 + 2(a+0.5)(b+1). So we have \mbox{Lower sum } = \sum_{(a,b)} 0.5(1+2ab) = 0.5 \sum_{(a,b)} 1+2ab = 8 + 0.5\sum_{(a,b)}2 ab Since a=0, 0.5, 1, 1.5 and b= 0, 1, 2, 3, expanding this sum gives \mbox{Lower} = 8 + 0.5 (0 + 0 + 0 + 0 + 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 0 + 2 + 4 + 6 + 0 + 3 + 6 + 9) = 26.
Similarly, we can compute the upper sum: \mbox{Upper sum }= \sum_{(a,b)}0.5(1+2(a+0.5)(b+1)) = 0.5\sum_{(a,b)}(1+2(a+0.5)(b+1)) = 8 + 0.5\sum_{(a,b)}(a+0.5)(b+1) = 58.

statement.p: The figure below shows the distribution of temperature, in degrees C, in a 5 meter by 5 meter heated room.
Using Riemann sums, estimate the average temperature in the room.
average temperature =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Let's break up the room into 25 sections, each of which is 1 meter by 1 meter and has area \Delta A=1.
We shall begin our sum as an upper estimate starting with the lower left corner of the room and continue across the bottom and moving upward using the highest temperature, T_i, in each case. So the upper Riemann sum becomes \sum_{i=1}^{25} T_i \Delta A = T_1 \Delta A + T_2 \Delta A + T_3 \Delta A + \cdots + T_{25} \Delta A = \Delta A (T_1 + T_2 + T_3 + \cdots + T_{25}). Thus, taking the maximum value for each region (and, where the temperatures are not bounded in the box, taking the largest value plus one), we have \mbox{sum} = (1)(28 + 26 + 25 + 24 + 24 + 26 + 25 + 24 + 24 + 23 + 24 + 24 + 23 + 23 + 23 + 23 + 22 + 22 + 21 + 21 + 22 + 21 + 20 + 20 + 21) = 579.
In the same way, the lower Riemann sum is formed by taking the lowest temperature (and, where the temperatures are not bounded in the box, taking the largest value minus one), t_i, in each case: \sum_{i=1}^{25} t_i \Delta A = t_1 \Delta A + t_2 \Delta A + t_3 \Delta A + \cdots + t_{25} \Delta A = \Delta A (t_1 + t_2 + t_3 + \cdots + t_{25}). Thus, taking the minimum value for each region, we have \mbox{sum} = (1)(25 + 24 + 24 + 23 + 23 + 24 + 23 + 23 + 23 + 22 + 22 + 22 + 21 + 21 + 21 + 21 + 20 + 20 + 20 + 20 + 19 + 18 + 17 + 18 + 19) = 533.
So, averaging the upper and lower sums we get: 556.
To compute the average temperature, we divide by the area of the room, \mbox{Average temperature} = \frac{556}{25} = 22.24. That is, approximately 22.24^{\circ}C.

Answer: \mathbf{a} =

solution.p: SOLUTION

The given vector has length \left| \langle -6, 3, 6 \rangle \right| = \sqrt{(-6)^2+3^2+6^2}= \sqrt{81}, so a unit vector in the direction of \langle -6, 3, 6 \rangle is \mathbf u = \frac{1}{\sqrt{81}}\langle -6, 3, 6 \rangle.
A vector in the same direction but with length 3 is
\displaystyle 3 \mathbf u = \frac{3}{\sqrt{81}} \langle -6, 3, 6 \rangle = \left \langle \frac{-18}{\sqrt{81}} , \frac{9}{\sqrt{81}}, \frac{18}{\sqrt{81}} \right \rangle.

Decide, without calculation, if each of the integrals below are positive, negative, or zero. Let D be the region inside the unit circle centered at the origin. Let T, B, R, and L denote the regions enclosed by the top half, the bottom half, the right half, and the left half of unit circle, respectively.
The region W lies below the surface f(x,y) = 4 e^{-(x-3)^2-y^2} and above the disk x^2+y^2\le 36 in the xy-plane.
(a) Think about what the contours of f look like. You may want to using f(x,y)=1 as an example. Sketch a rough contour diagram on a separate sheet of paper.
(b) Write an integral giving the area of the cross-section of W in the plane x=3.
Area = \int_a^b d,
where a = and b =
(c) Use your work from (b) to write an iterated double integral giving the volume of W, using the work from (b) to inform the construction of the inside integral.
Volume = \int_a^b\int_c^d d d,
where a = , b = c = and d =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The contour f(x,y)=1 lies in the xy-plane and has equation 4 e^{-(x-3)^2-y^2} = 1, so -(x-3)^2-y^2 = \ln (1/4),\quad\mbox{or}\quad (x-3)^2+y^2 = \ln 4. This is the equation of a circle of radius \sqrt{\ln(4)} centered at (3,0) in the xy-plane. Similarly, for k \lt 4, we have that the contours f(x,y) = k are the circles (x - 3)^2 + y^2 = \ln(4/k), all of which are centered on (3,0).
(b) The cross-section has equation z=f(3,y)=4 e^{-y^2}. If x=3, the base region in the xy-plane extends from y=-\sqrt{27} to y=\sqrt{27}. Thus the area is \hbox{Area } = \int_{-\sqrt{27}}^{\sqrt{27}}4 e^{-y^2}\,dy.
(c) Using this idea and slicing parallel to the y-axis, we get \hbox{Volume } = \int_{-6}^{6}\int_{-\sqrt{36-x^2}}^{\sqrt{36-x^2}} 4 e^{-(x-3)^2-y^2}\,dy\,dx.

statement.p: probability =
(b) x \lt \frac{1}{2} + y:
probability =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The probability is \int_0^1\int_{1/2}^1 {2 \over 3} (x + 2y) \,dx\,dy = \int_0^1 {2\over3} ({1\over2}x^2 + 2xy)\bigr|^1_{1/2}\,dy = \int_0^1 {2\over3} \left[({1\over2} + 2y) - ({1\over 8} + {}y)\right]\,dy = {2\over3}\int_0^1 (\frac{3}{8} + y) \, dy = {2\over3} \left(\frac{3}{8} y + \frac{1}{2} y^2\right)\bigr|_0^1 = {2\over3} \left(\frac{7}{8}\right) = \frac{7}{12}.
(b) It is easier to calculate the probability that x \lt \frac1{2} + y does not happen, that is, the probability that x \ge \frac1{2} + y, and subtract it from 1. The probability that x \ge \frac1{2} + y is \int_{0}^{1/2}\int_{y+1/2}^{1} {2\over3} (x+2y) \,dx\,dy = \int_{0}^{1/2} (\frac13\,x^2 + \frac43\,xy) \bigr|_{y+(1/2)}^{1} \,dy = \int_{0}^{1/2} \frac13\left(1 - (\frac1{2} + y)^2\right) + \frac43(y)(1 - (\frac1{2} + y)) \,dy = \int_{0}^{1/2} -\frac53\,y^2 + \frac{1}{3} y + \frac{1}{4} \, dy = (-\frac59\,y^3 + \frac{1}{6}\, y^2 + \frac{1}{4}\,y)\bigr|_{0}^{1/2} = \frac{7}{72}. Thus, the probability that x \lt \frac1{2}+y is 1-(\frac{7}{72}) = \frac{65}{72}.

statement.p: Resolve the following vectors into components:
(a) The vector \vec v in 2-space of length 7 pointing up at an angle of \pi/3 measured from the positive x-axis.
\vec v = \vec i + \vec j
(b) The vector \vec w in 3-space of length 5 lying in the xz-plane pointing upward at an angle of \pi/4 measured from the positive x-axis.
\vec v = \vec i + \vec j + \vec k

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The components are v_1 = 7 \cos \pi/3 = (7)({1\over 2}) = {7 \over 2} and v_2 = 7 \sin \pi/3 = (7)({\sqrt 3\over 2}) = {7\sqrt 3 \over 2}. Thus \vec v = {7 \over 2}\,\vec i + {7\sqrt 3 \over 2}\,\vec j.
(b) Since the vector lies in the xz-plane, its y-component is 0. Its x-component is (5)(\cos \pi/4) = {5\over\sqrt 2}, and and its z-component is (5)(\sin \pi/4) = {5\over\sqrt 2}. So the vector is \vec w = {5\over\sqrt 2}\,\vec i + {5\over\sqrt 2}\,\vec k.

Convert the integral \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{-x}^x\,dy\,dx to polar coordinates and evaluate it (use t for \theta):
With a = , b = , c = and d = ,

static.solution:
SOLUTION
In polar coordinates, -\pi/4\le\theta\le\pi/4. Also, the outer (right) boundary of the region is \sqrt{2} = x = r\cos\theta. Hence, 0\le r\le \sqrt{2}/\cos\theta. The integral becomes \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{-x}^x\,dy\,dx =\int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\int_0^{\sqrt{2}/\!\cos\theta}\,r\,dr\,d\theta. Then \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\int_0^{\sqrt{2}/\!\cos\theta}\,r\,dr\,d\theta = \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\left(\frac{r^2}{2}\bigg|_0^{\sqrt{2}/\!\cos\theta}\right)\,d\theta = \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\frac{1}{\cos^2\theta}\,d\theta. And \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4}\frac{1}{\cos^2\theta}\,d\theta =1 \tan\theta\bigg|_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} = 1\cdot(1 - (-1)) = 2. Notice that we can check this answer because the integral gives the area of the shaded triangular region which is \frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{2} \cdot (2\sqrt{2}) = 2.

p.em: (If you find more than one vector, enter them in a comma-separated list.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the component of \vec v in the \,\mathit{\vec i}-direction is 8, we have \vec v = 8 \,\mathit{\vec i} + b \,\mathit{\vec j} for some b. Since ||\vec v|| = 17, we have \sqrt{8^2 + b^2} = 17^2, so b = 15 or b = -15. There are two vectors satisfying the properties given: \vec v = 8\,\mathit{\vec i}+15\,\mathit{\vec j}, 8\,\mathit{\vec i}-15\,\mathit{\vec j}.

statement.p: (a) Graph r=1/(5\cos\theta) for -\pi/2\le\theta\le\pi/2 and r=1. Then write an iterated integral in polar coordinates representing the area inside the curve r=1 and to the right of r=1/(5\cos\theta). (Use t for \theta in your work.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The curve r=1/(5\cos\theta), or r\cos\theta=1/5, is the line x = 1/5. The curve r=1 is the circle of radius 1 centered at the origin. This gives the graph
The line intersects the circle where 5\cos\theta=1, so \theta = \pm\arccos(1/5). Thus \hbox{Area }=\int_{-\arccos(1/5)}^{\arccos(1/5)}\int_{1/(5\cos\theta)}^1 r\,dr\,d\theta. Evaluating gives \hbox{Area }= \int_{-\arccos(1/5)}^{\arccos(1/5)}\left(\frac{r^2}{2}\bigg|_{1/(5\cos\theta)}^1\right)d\theta =\frac{1}{2}\int_{-\arccos(1/5)}^{\arccos(1/5)}\left(1-\frac{1}{25\cos^2\theta}\right)d\theta so \mbox{Area }=\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta -\frac{\tan\theta}{25}\right) \bigg|_{-\arccos(1/5)}^{\arccos(1/5)} =\frac{1}{2}\left(2(\arccos(1/5)) - 2\frac{\tan(\arccos(1/5))}{25}\right) = \arccos(\frac1{5}) - \frac1{25}\,\tan(\arccos(\frac1{5})).

statement.p: Parameterize the plane through the point (-4, -5, -4) with the normal vector \left\lt 3,4,-3\right>

p.em: (Use s and t for the parameters in your parameterization, and enter your vector as a single vector, with angle brackets: e.g., as \lt 1 + s + t, s - t, 3 - t \gt.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
To parameterize the plane we need two nonparallel vectors \vec v_1 and \vec v_2 that are parallel to the plane. Such vectors are perpendicular to the normal vector to the plane, \vec n = \left\lt 3,4,-3\right>. We can choose any vectors \vec v_1 and \vec v_2 such that \vec v_1\cdot \vec n = \vec v_2\cdot \vec n = 0.
One choice is \vec v_1 = \left\lt -4,3,0\right>, \qquad \vec v_2 = \left\lt 3,0,3\right>.
Letting \vec r_0 = \left\lt -4,-5,-4\right>, we have the parameterization \vec r(s, t) = \vec r_0+ s\vec v_1+t\vec v_2 = \left\lt 3t-\left(4+4s\right),3s-5,3t-4\right>.

statement.p: Parameterize a vase formed by rotating the curve z= 6 \sqrt{x-1},\,1\leq x\leq 5, around the z-axis. Use s and t for your parameters.
y(s,t) = , and
z(s,t) = , with
\le s\le and

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The vase obtained by rotating the curve z=6\sqrt{x-1}, 1\le x\le 5, around the z-axis is shown in the figure below.
At height z, the cross-section is a horizontal circle of radius a. Thus, letting the angle \theta around the z-axis be t, a point on this horizontal circle is given by \vec r=a \cos t \vec i + a \sin t \vec j + z\vec k. However, the radius a and height z are not independent. We can parameterize easily in two ways: first, suppose that we take the radius a to be our second parameter, a = s. Then, the height z = 6\sqrt{s - 1}, and our parameterization is x(s,t) = s\cos t, y(s,t) = s\sin t, and z(s,t) = 6\sqrt{s - 1}, with 1\le s\le 5 \quad\mbox{and}\quad 0\le t\le 2\pi. Alternately, we could take the height z to be the second parameter, z = s. Then, solving for the radius r in the expression for the curve, we get a = \left(\frac{s}{6}\right)^2 + 1. Thus in this case the parameterization is x(s,t) = \left((\frac{s}{6})^2 + 1\right)\,\cos(t), y(s,t) = \left((\frac{s}{6})^2 + 1\right)\,\sin(t), and z(s,t) = s, with 0\le s\le 12\quad\mbox{and}\quad 0\le t\le 2\pi.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We use spherical coordinates with \phi = s and \theta = t as the two parameters. Since the radius is 5, we can take x = 5\cos\!\left(t\right)\sin\!\left(s\right), \quad y = 5\sin\!\left(t\right)\sin\!\left(s\right), \quad \mbox{and}\quad z = 5\cos\!\left(s\right), with 0\le s\le\pi\quad\mbox{and}\quad 0\le t\le 2\pi.

A decorative oak post is 30 inches long and is turned on a lathe so that its profile is sinusoidal as shown in the figure below.
In this figure, r_0 = 6 inches and a_0 = 10 inches.
(a) Describe the surface of the post parametrically using cylindrical coordinates and the parameters s and t.
y(s,t) = , and
z(s,t) = , where
\le s\le and
\le t\le .
(b) Find the volume of the post.
volume =

p.em: (Include units.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Let z be measured from the bottom of the post, and the center of the post be at x = 0, y = 0. The surface is the revolution surface obtained by revolving a curve extending vertically along one edge of the surface around the z axis, as suggested by the figure below.
From the measurements given, we obtain the equation of the curve x = \cos \left( \frac{\pi}{5} z \right) + 5, \qquad 0 \leq z \leq 30.
Rotating this around the z-axis, taking z=s and \theta = t as the parameters, we get the parametric equations x = (\cos \left( \frac{\pi}{5} s \right)+5)\cos t, y = (\cos \left( \frac{\pi}{5} s \right)+5)\sin t, and z = s, with 0 \leq s \leq 30, \qquad 0 \leq t \leq 2\pi.
(b) We know that the points in the curve consists of cross-sections of circles parallel to the xy plane and of radius \cos((\pi/{5})z+5). Thus, \mbox{Area of cross-section} = \pi\left(\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{5}z+5\right)\right)^2 Integrating over z, we get \hbox{Volume } = \pi \int_0^{30} \left(\cos\frac{\pi}{5} z+5\right)^2 dz = \pi \int_0^{30} \left(\cos^2\frac{\pi}{5}z+10\cos\frac{\pi}{5}z +25 \right) dz = 765 \pi \mbox{ in}^3.

statement.p: Find the triple integral of the function f(x,y,z) = x^{3}\cos\!\left(y+z\right) over the cube 2 \leq x \leq 3, 0 \leq y \leq \pi, 0 \leq z \leq \pi.

Find the mass of the solid bounded by the xy-plane, yz-plane, xz-plane, and the plane (x/3)+(y/3)+(z/9) = 1, if the density of the solid is given by \delta (x,y,z)=x + 3 y.
mass =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The region of integration the region in the first octant below the plane z = 9 - 3 x - 3 y. Note that the projection of this into the xy-plane is the triangular region below y = 3 - x.
The mass of the volume is then M = \int_R \delta\,dV = \int_0^3\int_0^{3 - x}\int_0^{9-3 x-3 y}\,x + 3 y\,dz\,dy\,dx. Integrating with respect to z, M = \int_0^3\int_0^{3 - x} (x + 3 y)(9-3 x-3 y)\,dy\,dx so that M = \int_0^3\int_0^{3 - x} -3 x^2 + 9 x - 3 x y - 9 x y + 27 y - 9 y^2\,dy\,dx. Then, integrating with respect to y, M = \int_0^3 (-3 x^2 + 9 x)(3 - x) + \frac12(27 - 12 x)(3 - x)^2 - 3 (3 - x)^3\,dx. Expanding the these terms, we have M = \int_0^3 0 x^3 + \frac{9}{2} x^2 - 27 x + \frac{81}{2}\, dx = \frac{81}{2}.

The moment of inertia of a solid body about an axis in 3-space relates the angular acceleration about this axis to torque (force twisting the body). The moments of inertia about the coordinate axes of a body of constant density and mass m occupying a region W of volume V are defined to be I_x = \frac{m}{V}\int_W (y^2+z^2) \,dV\qquad I_y = \frac{m}{V}\int_W (x^2+z^2) \,dV\qquad I_z = \frac{m}{V}\int_W (x^2+y^2) \,dV
Use these definitions to find the moment of inertia about the z-axis of the rectangular solid of mass 60 given by 0 \le x \le 4, 0 \le y \le 1, 0 \le z \le 5.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The volume V of the solid is 4 \cdot 1 \cdot 5 = 20. Thus for I_x we have I_x = \frac{60}{20}\int_W\, y^2 + z^2\,dV = 3\int_0^4\int_0^1\int_0^5\,y^2 + z^2\,dz\,dy\,dx. This is I_x = 3\int_0^4\int_0^1 y^2 z + \frac13 z^3\bigg|_{z=0}^{z=5} = 3\int_0^{4}\int_0^{1}\, 5 y^2 + \frac{125}{3}\, dy\,dx, or I_x = 3\int_0^4 \frac{5}{3} + \frac{125}{3}\, dx = 520.
Similarly, I_y = 820,\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad I_z = 340.

Assume x, y, z are in cm. Let C be a solid cone with both height and radius 1 and contained between the surfaces z=\sqrt{x^2+y^2} and z=1. If C has constant mass density of 1 g/cm^3, find the z-coordinate of C's center of mass.

p.em: (Include units.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The total volume of the cone is \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h = \frac{1}{3}\pi, so the total mass is \frac{1}{3} \pi (since the density is always 1). The center of mass z-coordinate is given by \overline{z} = \frac{3}{ \pi} \int_C z \,dV Using cylindrical coordinates to evaluate this integral gives \overline{z} = \frac{3}{ \pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{1} \int_0^z 1 z r\,dr \,dz \,d\theta, so \overline{z} = \frac{3}{ \pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{1} 1\cdot \frac{z^3}{2} \,dz \,d\theta = \left(\frac{3}{ \pi}\right)\left(2\pi\right) 1\cdot \frac{1}{8} = \frac{3}{4}\mbox{ cm}.

The density, \delta, of the cylinder x^2+y^2\le 9, 0\le z\le 3 varies with the distance, r, from the z-axis: \delta = 1 + r\mbox{ g}/\mbox{cm}^3. Find the mass of the cylinder, assuming x,y,z are in cm.
mass =

p.em: (Include units.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The cylinder has radius 3. Using cylindrical coordinates to find the mass and integrating with respect to r first, we have \mbox{mass} = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^{3}\int_0^{3}(1+r)r\,dr\,dz\,d\theta = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^{3} \left(1\frac{r^2}2+\frac{r^3}3 \right) \Bigg|_0^{3}\,dz\,d\theta = 2\pi \cdot 3\cdot \left(\frac{9}2+\frac{27}3\right) = 81\pi\mbox{ g}.

Find the absolute value of the Jacobian, \left|\frac{\partial (x,y)}{\partial (s,t)}\right|, for the change of variables given by x = 7s+5t, y = 8s+6t

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We have \frac{\partial (x,y)}{\partial (s,t)} = \left|\begin{array}{ccc} x_s \amp x_t\\ y_s\amp y_t \end{array}\right| =\left|\begin{array}{ccc} 7 \amp 5 \\ 8 \amp 6 \end{array}\right| = 2. Therefore, \left|\frac{\partial (x,y)}{\partial (s,t)}\right|=2.

statement.p: For each of the following, perform the indicated operations on the vectors
\vec a = 5\,\mathit{\vec j}+4\,\mathit{\vec k}, \vec b = -5\,\mathit{\vec i}+2\,\mathit{\vec j}+\,\mathit{\vec k}, \vec z = 3\,\mathit{\vec i}+\,\mathit{\vec j}.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) 3 \vec a + 5 \vec b = 3 (5\,\mathit{\vec j}+4\,\mathit{\vec k}) + 5 (-5\,\mathit{\vec i}+2\,\mathit{\vec j}+\,\mathit{\vec k}) = -25\,\mathit{\vec i}+25\,\mathit{\vec j}+17\,\mathit{\vec k}.
(b) 4 \vec a + 6 \vec b - 3 \vec z = 4 (5\,\mathit{\vec j}+4\,\mathit{\vec k}) + 6 (-5\,\mathit{\vec i}+2\,\mathit{\vec j}+\,\mathit{\vec k}) - 3 (3\,\mathit{\vec i}+\,\mathit{\vec j}) = -39\,\mathit{\vec i}+29\,\mathit{\vec j}+22\,\mathit{\vec k}.

statement.p: Find the Jacobian. \frac{\partial (x,y,z)}{\partial (s,t,u)}, where x = 4s-3t-2u, y = -\left(2s+t+4u\right), z = 4t-4s+4u.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We have \left|\frac{\partial (x,y,z)}{\partial (s,t,u)}\right| = \left|\begin{array}{ccc} x_s \amp x_t \amp x_u\\ y_s \amp y_t \amp y_u\\ z_s \amp z_t \amp z_u \end{array}\right| =\left|\begin{array}{ccc} 4 \amp -3 \amp -2\\ -2 \amp -1 \amp -4\\ -4 \amp 4 \amp 4 \end{array}\right|. This 3 \times 3 determinant is computed the same way as for the cross product, with the entries 4,-3,-2 in the first row playing the same role as \vec i,\vec j,\vec k. We get \frac{\partial (x,y,z)}{\partial (s,t,u)}= ((-1)(4)-(-4)(4))4 + ((-4)(-4)-(-2)(4))-3 + ((-2)(4)-(-1)(-4))-2 = 0.

Use the change of variables s=y, t=y-x^2 to evaluate \int\int_R x \,dx\,dy over the region R in the first quadrant bounded by y=0, y=16, y=x^2, and y=x^2-2.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We must change variables in the area element dA=\,dx\,dy, the integrand x and the region R.
Inverting the variable change gives x=\sqrt{s-t}, y=s where we use the positive square root because the region R is in the first quadrant where x\ge 0. Thus \frac{\partial (x, y)}{\partial (s, t)}= \left\vert \begin{array}{cc}\frac{\partial x}{\partial s}\amp \frac{\partial x}{\partial t}\\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial s}\amp \frac{\partial y}{\partial t}\end{array}\right\vert =\left\vert \begin{array}{cc}1/(2\sqrt{s-t})\amp \quad -1/(2\sqrt{s-t})\\ 1\amp 0\end{array}\right\vert = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{s-t}}. Therefore dx\,dy = \left\vert \frac{\partial (x, y)}{\partial (s, t)}\right\vert \,ds\,dt =\frac{1}{2\sqrt{s-t}} \,ds\,dt.
The integrand is x = \sqrt{s-t}.
The region of integration can be transformed by examination of its boundaries. The left and right boundaries of R are given by y-x^2=t=0 and y-x^2 = t =-2. The bottom and top boundaries of given by y=s=0 and y=s=16.
Let T be the rectangle 0\le s\le 16, -2\le t \le 0 of area (2)(16)= 32. We have \int\int_R x\,dx\,dy= \int\int_T \sqrt{s-t}\frac{1}{2\sqrt{s-t}} \,ds\,dt= \frac{1}{2}(\hbox{Area of T}) = 16.

statement.p: Use the change of variables s = x + y, t = y to find the area of the ellipse x^2 + 2 x y + 2 y^2 \le 1.
area =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The area of the ellipse is \int\int_R \,dx\,dy where R is the region x^2 + 2 x y + 2 y^2\le 1. We must change variables in both the area element dA=\,dx\,dy and the region R.
Inverting the variable change gives x = s - t, y = t. Thus \frac{\partial (x, y)}{\partial (s, t)}= \left\vert \begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s}\amp \frac{\partial x}{\partial t}\\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial s}\amp \frac{\partial y}{\partial t} \end{array} \right\vert = \left\vert \begin{array}{cr} 1 \amp -1\\ 0\amp 1 \end{array} \right\vert = 1. Therefore dx\,dy= \left\vert \frac{\partial (x, y)}{\partial (s, t)}\right\vert \,ds\,dt = \,ds\,dt.
The region of integration is x^2 + 2 x y + 2 y^2 = (s - t)^2+ 2(s - t)t + 2 t^2 = s^2+t^2\le 1.
Let T be the unit disc s^2+t^2\le 1. We have \int\int_R \,dx\,dy= \int\int_T \,ds\,dt = \hbox{Area of }T = \pi.

statement.p: Use the change of variables s=xy, t=xy^2 to compute \int_R xy^2\,dA, where R is the region bounded by xy=2,\ xy=7,\ xy^2=2,\ xy^2=7.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Given \begin{array}{ccc}s\amp =\amp xy\\t\amp =\amp xy^2,\end{array}. we have \frac{\partial(s,t)}{\partial(x,y)}= \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{\partial s}{\partial x} \amp \frac{\partial s}{\partial y}\\ \frac{\partial t}{\partial x} \amp \frac{\partial t}{\partial y} \end{array}\right| =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}y\amp x\\y^2\amp 2xy\end{array}\right|=xy^2=t. Since \frac{\partial(s,t)}{\partial(x,y)}\cdot \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}=1, \qquad \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}=\frac{1}{t}.
So \int_R xy^2\,dA=\int_{T}t\left|\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right|\,ds\,dt= \int_{T}t\,(\frac 1t)\,ds\,dt=\int_{T}\,ds\,dt, where T is the region bounded by s=2, s=7, t=2, t=7. Then \int_Rxy^2\,dA=\int_2^{7}\,ds\int_2^{7}\,dt=25.

statement.p: Find positive numbers a and b so that the change of variables s=ax, t=by transforms the integral \int\int_R \,dx\,dy into \int\int_T \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert \,ds\,dt for the region R, the rectangle 0\le x \le 40, 0\le y \le 45 and the region T, the square 0\le s, t \le 1.
What is \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert in this case?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The square T is defined by the inequalities 0 \le s = ax \le 1 \qquad 0\le t=by\le 1 that correspond to the inequalities 0\le x \le 1/a = 40 \qquad 0\le y \le 1/b = 45 that define R. Thus a=1/40 and b=1/45.
Then, we have x = 40 s and y = 45 t, so \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert = \left|\begin{array}{cc} 40 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 45 \end{array}\right| = 1800.

statement.p: Find a number a so that the change of variables s=x+ay, t=y transforms the integral \int\int_R \,dx\,dy over the parallelogram R in the xy-plane with vertices (0,0), (22,0), (-24,14), (-2,14) into an integral \int\int_T \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert\,ds\,dt over a rectangle T in the st-plane.
What is \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert in this case?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Inverting the change of variables gives x = s-at, y=t. The four edges of R are y=0, y=14, y=-\frac{7}{12} x, y=-\frac{7}{12} (x-22). The change of variables transforms the edges to t=0, t=14, t=-\frac{7}{12} s + \frac{7}{12} at, t=-\frac{7}{12} s + \frac{7}{12} at + \frac{77}{6}. These are equations for the edges of a rectangle in the st-plane if the last two are of the form: s=(\hbox{Constant}). This happens when the t terms drop out, or a=\frac{12}{7}. With a=\frac{12}{7} the change of variables gives \int\int_T \left\vert \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert \,ds\,dt over the rectangle T: 0\le t \le 14, 0\le s\le 22.
The jacobian \left\vert\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert is \left\vert\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right\vert = \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp -\frac{12}{7} \\ 0 \amp 1 \end{array} \right\vert = 1.

statement.p: In this problem we use the change of variables x=4 s + t, y = s - t to compute the integral \int_R (x+y)\,dA, where R is the parallelogram with vertices (x,y)=(0,0), (8,2), (10,0), and (2,-2).
First find the magnitude of the Jacobian, \left|\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right| = .
Then, with a = , b = ,
c = , and d = ,
\int_R (x+y)\,dA = \int_a^b\,\int_c^d\, ( s + t + )\; dt\, ds =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Given \begin{array}{ccc} x \amp = \amp 4 s + t\\ y \amp = \amp s - t, \end{array} we have \left|\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right| = \left|\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s} \amp \frac{\partial x}{\partial t}\\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial s} \amp \frac{\partial y}{\partial t} \end{array}\right| =\left|\begin{array}{cc} 4 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \end{array}\right| = |-5|, hence \left|\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right| = 5. We therefore get \int_R (x+y) \,dA = \int_{T} ((4 s + t) + (s - t)) \left|\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(s,t)}\right|dsdt = \int_{T}(5s)(5)\,ds\,dt=\int_{T} (5\cdot 5s)\,ds\,dt, where T is the region in the st-plane corresponding to R.
Now, we need to find T.
Because \begin{array}{ccc} x \amp = \amp 4 s+ t \\ y \amp = \amp s - t \end{array} we can use the boundaries of the region R to find the boundaries of T. Using the four vertices of the parallelogram R, we the edges y = \frac1{4}\,x, y = -x, y = \frac{1}{4}\,(x-2) - 2 and y = -(x - 8) + 2. So, from the above transformation, the boundaries are t = 0, s = 0, t = 2 and s = 2. Therefore \int_R(x+y)\,dA = \int_{0}^{2} \int_{0}^{2}\, 5\cdot 5s \,ds\,dt = 100. (Alternately, we could of course also write the integral as \int_{2}^{0} \int_{2}^{0}\, 5\cdot 5s \,ds\,dt.)

statement.p: Find the value(s) of a making \vec v = 3 a\,\vec i - 2\, \vec j parallel to \vec w = a^2\,\vec i + 4\, \vec j.

p.em: (If there is more than one value of a, enter the values as a comma-separated list.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
If two vectors are parallel, they are scalar multiples of one another. Thus, if a\ne 0, \frac{a^2}{2 a} = \frac{4}{-2}. Solving, and noticing that a = 0 also gives parallel vectors, gives a = 0, -6.

statement.p: (a) Find a unit vector from the point P=(1,1) and toward the point Q=(16,9).
(b) Find a vector of length 34 pointing in the same direction.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The displacement from P to Q is given by \overrightarrow{PQ} = (16\,\vec i + 9\,\vec j) - (1\,\vec i + 1\,\vec j) = 15\,\mathit{\vec i}+8\,\mathit{\vec j}. Since \mbox{len}{\overrightarrow{PQ}} = \sqrt{15^2 + 8^2} = 17, a unit vector \vec u in the direction of \overrightarrow{PQ} is given by \vec u = \frac{1}{17}\,\overrightarrow{PQ} = \frac{1}{17}\,(15\,\mathit{\vec i}+8\,\mathit{\vec j}) .
(b) A vector of length 34 pointing in the same direction is given by 34\,\vec u = \frac{34}{17}\,(15\,\mathit{\vec i}+8\,\mathit{\vec j}) = 30\,\mathit{\vec i}+16\,\mathit{\vec j}.

Suppose \vec v\cdot \vec w=7 and ||\vec v\times\vec w|| = 3, and the angle between \vec v and \vec w is \theta. Find

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Since \vec v\cdot \vec w= ||\vec v||\,||\vec w||\cos \theta and ||\vec v\times\vec w||=||\vec v||\, ||\vec w||\sin\theta, \tan \theta = \frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta} = \frac{||\vec v\times\vec w||}{\vec v\cdot \vec w} = \frac{3}{7} = 0.428571.
(b) Then \theta = \tan^{-1}(0.428571) = 0.404892.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The figure below shows the two lines the plane must contain.
Both lines are parallel to the y-axis; thus our plane must have y-slope zero. On the other hand, the line in the xy-plane is 3 units down and unit in front of of the line in the x z-plane; hence the x-slope of our plane must be -1.5. Thus the equation is z = 0 y - 1.5 x + c, for some constant c. Since the plane contains the point (0,0,3), the value of c must be 3. So the equation is z = -1.5 x + 3. This is shown in the graph below.

A store sells CDs at one price and DVDs at another price. The figure below shows the revenue (in dollars) of the music store as a function of the number, c, of CDs and the number, d, of DVDs that it sells. The values of the revenue are shown on each line.

p.em: (Hint: for this problem there are many possible ways to estimate the requisite values; you should be able to find information from the figure that allows you to give an answer that is essentially exact.)

statement.p: (a) What is the price of a CD? dollars
(b) What is the price of a DVD? dollars

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The revenue function, R, is linear and so we may write it as: R = (p_1)c + (p_2)d where p_1 is the price of CDs and p_2 is the price of DVDs, in dollars. From the diagram, we can pick two points, such as c = 150, d=250 on the contour R=5000, and c = 250, d = 250 on the contour R = 6000. These points give the following system of linear equations: 5000 = 150 p_1 + 250 p_2, \mbox{ and } 6000 = 250 p_1 + 250 p_2. Solving gives p_1 = 10 dollars and p_2 = 14 dollars.

statement.p: (a) Suppose that a 160 lb person and a 180 person both go 10 miles, the first at 11 mph and the second at 10 mph.
How many calories does the 160 lb person burn?
How many calories does the 180 lb person burn?
(b) We might also be interested in the number of calories each person burns per pound of their weight.
How many calories per pound does the 160 lb person burn?
How many calories per pound does the 180 lb person burn?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The time in minutes to go 10 miles at a speed of s mph is (10/s)(60)= 600/s. Thus the 160 lb person going 11 mph uses (10.8)(600/11) = 589.091 calories, and the 180 lb person going 10 mph uses (10.2)(600/10) = 612 calories.
(b) The 160 lb person burns 589.091/160 = 3.68182 calories per pound for the trip, while the 180 lb person burns 612/180 = 3.4 calories per pound for the trip.

static.solution:
Substitute (x,y) = \left(-3,4\right) to find f(-3,4) = -3 + 4(-3)^{4} = 321.
Similarly, with (x,y) = \left(4,5\right) we find f(4,5) = 4 + 5(4)^{4} = 1284.
Finally, for (x,y) = \left(5,2\right) we find f(5,2) = 5 + 2(5)^{4} = 1255.

li.p: The parametric curve x = (3t+4)^2, y = 5(3t+4)^2-9, for 0 \leq t \leq 3 is a line segment.
A parametrization of the graph of y = \ln(x) for x > 0 is given by x = e^t, y = t for -\infty \lt t \lt \infty.
The line parametrized by x = 7, y = 5t, z = 6 + t is parallel to the x-axis.

solution.p: SOLUTION
1. Eliminating the parameter t yields the equation y = 5x -9,\; 16 \le x \le 169. Thus the parametric curve is a line segment and the statement is True.
2. Substituting x = e^t, y = t into the equation y= \ln(x) yields t = \ln(e^t) = t. For the given values of t, x > 0. Thus the statement is True.
3. The direction vector of the line is \langle 0, 5, 1\rangle. This vector is not parallel to the x-axis. Thus the statement is False.

Sketch a contour diagram of each function. Then, decide whether its contours are predominantly lines, parabolas, ellipses, or hyperbolas.

solution.p: SOLUTION
1. The contours have equation k = x^2+ 4 y^2 , which (for k >0) represent ellipses in the xy- plane.
2. The contours have equation k = x^2- 2 y^2 , which represent hyperbolas in the xy- plane.
3. The contours have equation k = -5 x^2. For k \le 0, these equations are equivalent to x = \pm \sqrt{-k/5}, which represent vertical lines in the xy- plane.
4. The contours have equation k = y-4 x^2 , which represent parabolas in the xy- plane.

A child wanders slowly down a circular staircase from the top of a tower. With x,y,z in feet and the origin at the base of the tower, her position t minutes from the start is given by x=30\cos t,\quad y = 30 \sin t, \quad z = 120 - 5 t.
(a) How tall is the tower?
height = ft
(b) When does the child reach the bottom?
time = minutes
(c) What is her speed at time t?
speed = ft/min
(d) What is her acceleration at time t?
acceleration = ft/min{}^2

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Since z=120 feet when t=0, the tower is 120 feet high.
(b) The child reaches the bottom when z=0, so t=120/5=24 minutes.
(c) Her velocity is given by \vec v =\frac{d\vec r}{dt} = -(30\sin t)\vec i +(30\cos t)\vec j - 5\vec k, so \hbox{Speed} = ||\vec v|| = \sqrt{(-30\sin t)^2+(30\cos t)^2 + (-5)^2} = \sqrt{30^2 + 5^2} = \sqrt{925} \mbox{ ft/min}.
(c) Her acceleration is given by \vec a = \frac{d\vec v}{dt} = -(30 \cos t)\vec i -(30 \sin t)\vec j \mbox{ ft/min}^2.

statement.p: Find the length of the curve x = t-5,\quad y = 5+4t, z = 2+2t, for 4 \le t \le 6.
length =

p.em: (Think of second way that you could calculate this length, too, and see that you get the same result.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We have \hbox{Length} = \int_4^6 \sqrt{(x'(t))^2 + (y'(t))^2 + (z'(t))^2}\,dt = \int_{4}^{6} \sqrt{(1)^2+(4)^2+(2)^2}\,dt = 2\sqrt{21}. This is the length of a straight line from the point (-1,21,10) to (1,29,14).

Find the limits, if they exist, or type DNE for any which do not exist.
1) Along the x-axis:
2) Along the y-axis:
3) Along the line y=mx :
4) The limit is:
(a) Suppose that we consider (x,y)\to (0,0) along the curve y = 4 x. Find the limit in this case:
(b) Now consider (x,y)\to (0,0) along the curve y = 5 x. Find the limit in this case:
(c) Note that the results from (a) and (b) indicate that f has no limit as (x,y)\to (0,0) (be sure you can explain why!).
To show this more generally, consider (x,y)\to (0,0) along the curve y = m x, for arbitrary m. Find the limit in this case:

p.em: (Be sure that you can explain how this result also indicates that f has no limit as (x,y)\to(0,0).

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We want to show that f does not have a limit as (x,y) approaches (0,0).
(a) If (x,y) tends to (0,0) along the curve y = 4 x, then f(x,y) = f(x,4 x) = \frac{4x^{2}-\left(4x\right)^{2}}{x^{2}+\left(4x\right)^{2}} = \frac{-12}{17}.
Therefore \lim_{x\to0} f(x,4 x) = \frac{-12}{17}.
(b) Similarly, if (x,y) tends to (0,0) along the curve y = 5 x, then f(x,y) = f(x,5 x) = \frac{4x^{2}-\left(5x\right)^{2}}{x^{2}+\left(5x\right)^{2}} = \frac{-21}{26},
and so \lim_{x\to0} f(x,5 x) = \frac{-21}{26}.
Because we have two different values for these limits, we know that the function doesn't have a limit at (0,0). No matter how close we are to the origin, there will be points on f(x,y) that are close to \frac{-12}{17} and points that are close to \frac{-21}{26}, whereas for the limit to exist the function must get close to a single value.
(c) We can see this more generally by considering the limit as (x,y) tends to (0,0) along the curve y = m x. Then f(x,y) = f(x,m x) = \frac{4-m^{2}}{1+m^{2}}, so that \lim_{x\to0} f(x,m x) = \frac{4-m^{2}}{1+m^{2}}, and we see for every different value of m we will get a different limiting value for the function. Thus the function does not have a limit at (0,0).

statement.p: Show that the function f(x,y) = \frac{x^{3}y}{x^{6}+y^{3}}. does not have a limit at (0,0) by examining the following limits.
(a) Find the limit of f as (x,y) \to (0,0) along the line y = x.
(b) Find the limit of f as (x,y)\to(0,0) along the curve y = x^3.

p.em: (Be sure that you are able to explain why the results in (a) and (b) indicate that f does not have a limit at (0,0)!

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Let us suppose that (x,y) approaches (0,0) along the line y=x. Then f(x,y) = f(x,x) = \frac{x^4}{x^{6} + x^3} = \frac{x}{x^3+1}. Therefore \lim_{^{(x,y)\to(0,0)}_{y=x}} f(x,y) = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x}{x^3+1} = 0.
(b) On the other hand, if (x,y) approaches (0,0) along the curve y=x^3 we have f(x,y)=f(x,x^3) = \frac{x^{6}}{x^{6} + x^{9}} = 1 and so \lim_{^{(x,y)\to(0,0)}_{y=x^3}} f(x,y) = \lim_{x\to0}f(x,x^3) = 1.
Thus no matter how close they are to the origin, there will be points (x,y) such that f(x,y) is close to 0 and points (x,y) such that f(x,y) is close to 1. So the limit \lim_{(x,y)\to(0,0)} f(x,y) does not exist.
